head.title: Rep. Frank Announces Plans to Seek 6th Term

hedline.hl1: Rep. Frank Announces Plans to Seek 6th Term

block.p: LEAD: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts announced today that he would seek re-election even though the House ethics committee has yet to release a report on questions surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute.

LEAD: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts announced today that he would seek re-election even though the House ethics committee has yet to release a report on questions surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute.

Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts announced today that he would seek re-election even though the House ethics committee has yet to release a report on questions surrounding his relationship with a male prostitute.

Mr. Frank, a 50-year-old liberal Democrat who is serving his fifth term in Congress, had said he would decide about seeking re-election after the report was released. But in a statement released by his office, he said the political calendar had pushed him to make an earlier decision.
Mr. Frank, who in 1987 became the first member of Congress to disclose that he is a homosexual, noted that the report was not yet available and that the deadline for nominating petitions was May 8.
No other Democrat has announced for the seat. The Republicans have fielded two little-known candidates.

The Washington Times first reported Mr. Frank's relationship with a male prostitute last August, and published allegations that he was aware that a prostitution ring was being run out of his Capitol Hill apartment.
He apologized for ''poor judgment'' in hiring the prostitute but denied knowing about the prostitution ring.
The ethics panel plans to meet Thursday in a closed session, but a committee spokeswoman gave no indication whether the Congressman's case would be on the agenda.
